repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Power Distribution and Rural
            Electrification Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Power Distribution and
            Rural Electrification Project for Eritrea were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            contractor in the Asmara Distribution component obtained a
            court injunction in his home country against cashing of the
            unconditional performance bank guarantee leaving the
            Borrower with no immediate remedial option. A performance
            guarantee is meant to be irrevocable and this action of the
            contractor has very few precedents in Bank financed
            projects. The bank should examine this case to determine if
            there are lessons to be drawn for the terms of performance
            guarantees in Bank financed projects. When the Bank and
            Borrower relationship deteriorates to the point where the
            overall dialogue is not in the least constructive, the
            likelihood of negative spillover effects on projects should
            not be underestimated. In such an environment, when a
            project encounters implementation problems, there is little
            leverage that can be exerted through the overall country
            dialogue to resolve the problems.

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Power Distribution and Rural
            Electrification Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Power Distribution
            and Rural Electrification Project for Eritrea are: (i)
            expansion of electricity access in rural areas; (ii) improve
            the quality and adequacy of the electricity supply; and
            (iii) regulatory and institutional reforms in the sector to
            increase efficiency. The Borrower requested additional
            financing for the project on November 11, 2007. Project
            restructuring and additional financing was approved on June
            26, 2008. An amended and restated financing agreement was
            prepared that inter alia sought to extend the closing date
            of the original grant until June 30, 2010. Although the
            amended and restated financing agreement and related project
            agreements were signed on August 21, 2008, conditions of
            effectiveness were not met and the additional grant was
            withdrawn. As a consequence, the extension of the grant
            closing date did not occur. Following the withdrawal of the
            additional grant, the legal documents signed on September
            22, 2004, with respect to the original grant should have
            been amended to extend the closing date of the original
            grant to June 30, 2010, to allow for completion of
            activities. The retroactive extension of the closing date of
            the grant is necessary as otherwise the recipient will be
            required to refund the association the funds disbursed
            against the original grant from July 1, 2009 to date.

The objectives of the Power Distribution
            and Rural Electrification Project for Eritrea are: (i)
            expansion of electricity access in rural areas; (ii) improve
            the quality and adequacy of the electricity supply; and
            (iii) regulatory and institutional reforms in the sector to
            increase efficiency. The Borrower requested additional
            financing for the project on November 11, 2007. Project
            restructuring and additional financing was approved on June
            26, 2008. An amended and restated financing agreement was
            prepared that inter alia sought to extend the closing date
            of the original grant until June 30, 2010. Although the
            amended and restated financing agreement and related project
            agreements were signed on August 21, 2008, conditions of

            closing date did not occur. Following the withdrawal of the

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Power Distribution and Rural
            Electrification Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This additional grant to the state of
            Eritrea for the Power Distribution and Rural Electrification
            Project. This additional grant will support the completion
            of the ongoing part A: the Asmara component of the project
            to rehabilitate the distribution system in the city in view
            of cost overruns arising from higher unit costs of
            electrical materials. The additional grant will also support
            a new component for the overhaul and rehabilitation of key
            power generation plants at Hirgigo, Beleza and Assab.
            Overhaul and rehabilitation of the generation plants will
            ensure that electricity supply is maintained and outages are
            avoided. Overhaul has been postponed as the cost of the
            replacement parts could not be funded from European Economic
            Community (EEC's) capital expenditure program. While
            well operated power companies finance the rehabilitation of
            their generation plants from internal funds, EEC cannot
            presently do so as its revenues have been insufficient to
            meet its operating expenses since 2006 when international
            fuel prices began to raise. If oil prices had remained at
            their pre 2006 levels, EEC would have been able to carry out
            the rehabilitation from its internal resources.

repnme.cdata!:
Eritrea - Power Distribution and Rural
            Electrification Project

abstracts.cdata!:
In support of broad-based economic
            growth, the Eritrea Power Distribution and Rural
            Electrification Project aims to: (a) establish a sustainable
            program for expanding the population's access to
            electricity; and (b) improve the quality and reliability of
            electricity supply. To meet these objectives, the project
            will help finance three components: (1) the rehabilitation
            and expansion of the Asmara city distribution system; (2) a
            rural electrification program; and (3) a program for power
            sector reform and the building of  related institutional
            capacity to increase efficiency and attract private participation.

            Electrification Project
